page.title: 04 RIVER OTTER & FLOOD PLAIN
page.content:
Today the Otter provides a pleasant riverside walk,popular at weekends & during holidays,but in the past,it was essential to the economy of the area.Up to about 1450,it was navigable to Otterton(then a fishing village) and a wharf at Budleigh Haven(E.Bud's "port") handled wool & general merchandise. Silting up since the 1800's has removed trading possibilities.The flood plain here is about 0.5km wide & contrasts with the steep valley edge at Otterton. It is laid to permanent pasture but is naturally water-meadow which was drained from 1815 when an embankment & aquaduct were built to lead Budleigh Brook into the Otter.The Brook's course was further altered when the railway came in 1897.
By A.Kain & J.Ross
